page.text: This report presents the results of a Traffic Impact Study (TIS) for the proposed Kroger development in the
City of Royal Oak, Michigan. The subject site is located on the southwest corner of 12 Mile Road &
Stephenson Highway, as shown on Figure 1. The development is proposed to include a Kroger Marketplace
store, 18 pump fuel station, 3,840 square feet (SF) Bank, and approximately 4,500 SF of retail space. Site
access for the development is proposed via one driveway to 12 Mile Road, and three driveways each to
Edgeworth Avenue and Stephenson Highway. 12 Mile Road is under the jurisdiction of the Road Commission
for Oakland County (RCOC) and all other study roadways are under City jurisdiction.
The scope of this study was developed based on Fleis & VandenBrink (F&V) knowledge of the study area,
understanding of the development program, communication with City of Royal Oak, accepted traffic
engineering practice, and information published by the Institute of Transportation Engineers (ITE). The study
analyses were completed using Synchro and SimTraffic, Version 8 traffic analysis software. The study
intersections analyzed for this TIS include:
12 Mile Road & Matthews Hargreaves Chevrolet Driveway,
The purpose of this study is to identify the traffic related impacts, if any, of the proposed project on the
adjacent road network. Specific tasks undertaken for this study include the following:
1. Review of the proposed development plans, adjacent road network, and other background
2. Field reconnaissance of existing roadway and intersection geometrics, traffic controls, and speed
limits, and acquisition of traffic signal timing information from the City of Royal Oak and RCOC.
3. Collection of weekday PM (4:00 PM to 6:00 PM) peak period turning movement counts at the study
4. Identification of the existing PM peak hour traffic volumes at the study intersections.
5. Calculation of the Existing vehicle delays, Levels of Service (LOS), and vehicle queues at the study
intersections based on the methodologies of the Highway Capacity Manual, 2000 using Synchro and
6. Calculation of the future background traffic volumes based on an appropriate traffic growth rate to the
project build out year and/or any applicable background developments in the vicinity of this project.
7. Calculation of the Background (without the proposed development) vehicle delays, LOS, and
vehicle queues at the study intersections and identify improvements (if any) that would be required to
mitigate any unacceptable background traffic conditions.
8. Forecast the number of PM peak hour trips that would be generated by the proposed development
based on data published by the Institute of Transportation Engineers (ITE) in Trip Generation, 9
Edition and data provided by Kroger.
9. Assignment of the trips that would be generated by the proposed development to the adjacent road
network based on existing traffic patterns.
10. Combining of the site-generated traffic assignments with the background traffic forecasts to establish
the Future PM peak hour traffic volumes.
11. Calculation of the Future (with the proposed development) vehicle delays, LOS, and vehicle
queues at the study intersections and identification of improvements (if any) for the study road
network that would be required to accommodate the site-generated traffic volumes.
12. Evaluation of RCOC and City standards for right and left turn lanes at the proposed site driveways.
Sources of data for this study include traffic counts conducted by F&V and F&V subconsultant Traffic Data
Collection, Inc. (TDC), information provided by the developer, Southeast Michigan Council of Governments
(SEMCOG), City of Royal Oak, RCOC, and ITE. All background information is provided in Appendix A.
Vehicle transportation to and from the proposed development is provided via 12 Mile Road, Campbell Road,
and Stephenson Highway. Regional transportation is provided by I-75 which has an interchange with 12 Mile
Road approximately 900 feet east of Stephenson Highway. All study intersections are currently traffic signal
controlled except 12 Mile Road & Edgeworth Avenue, 12 Mile Road & Car Dealership Driveway, and the
proposed site access points which are STOP controlled on the minor approach. The lane use and traffic
control at the study intersections are shown on Figure 2 and the study roadways are further described below.
For the purposes of this study, all minor streets and driveways are assumed to have an operating speed of 25
12 Mile Road runs in the east and west directions with a posted speed limit of 30 and 40 mph to the west and
east of Campbell Road, respectively. The study section of 12 Mile Road is under the jurisdiction of RCOC
and is classified as an Urban Principal Arterial with an average daily traffic (ADT) volume of approximately
29,000 vehicles per day. The study section of 12 Mile Road has a typical 5-lane cross section with two lanes
in each direction and a center lane for left turns. Approximately ¼ mile west of Campbell Road, 12 Mile Road
tapers to a four lane cross section with two lanes in each direction.
Campbell Road runs in the north and south directions with a posted speed limit of 35 mph. Campbell Road
is under City jurisdiction and is classified as an Urban Minor Arterial with an ADT volume of approximately
17,000 vehicles per day. The study section of Campbell Road has a typical 5-lane cross section with two
lanes in each direction and a center lane for left turns. Approximately ½ mile south of 12 Mile Road,
Campbell Road tapers to a four lane cross section with two lanes in each direction.
Stephenson Highway runs in the north and south directions with a posted speed limit of 35 and 40 mph to
the south and north of 12 Mile Road, respectively. The study section of Stephenson Highway is under City
jurisdiction and is classified as an Urban Minor Arterial with an ADT of approximately 6,000 and 11,000
vehicles per day to the south and north of 12 Mile Road, respectively. South of 12 Mile Road, Stephenson
Highway is a typical 5-lane cross section with two lanes in each direction and a center lane for left turns.
Approximately ¼ mile south of 12 Mile Road and to the south, Stephenson Highway splits and forms a pair of
service drives for the I-75 freeway. North of 12 Mile Road, Stephenson Highway is constructed as a four-lane
boulevard roadway with indirect left turns accommodated via median crossovers.
Bellaire Avenue and Edgeworth Avenue provide access to Campbell Road and 12 Mile Road, respectively,
for several local businesses located east of Campbell Road and south of 12 Mile Road.
Existing traffic volume data at the study intersections were collected by F&V and F&V subconsultant Traffic
Data Collection, Inc. (TDC). Vehicular turning movement count data were collected in 15-minute intervals on
, 2014 between the hours of 4:00 PM and 6:00 PM. These data were used to
establish the current peak hour traffic volumes for the analysis of existing traffic conditions. The PM peak
hour of existing network traffic was identified to generally occur between 4:45 PM to 5:45 PM for a typical
The peak hour volumes for each intersection were utilized for this study and the volumes were balanced
upward through the study network. At locations where access is provided between study intersections,
“dummy” intersections were used to account for sink and source volumes, and through volumes were carried
along the main study roadways. Peak Hour Factors (PHF) were also calculated for each study intersection
approach. The traffic volume data are included in Appendix A and the existing peak hour traffic volumes are
Existing PM peak hour vehicle delays and Levels of Service (LOS) were calculated at the study intersections
using Synchro (Version 8) traffic analysis software. The results of the analysis of existing conditions were
based on the existing lane use and traffic control shown on Figure 2, the existing traffic volumes shown on
Figure 3, and the methodologies presented in the Highway Capacity Manual, 2000 (HCM). Additionally,
SimTraffic (Version 8) traffic simulations were utilized to evaluate network operations and vehicle queues.
Descriptions of LOS “A” through “F” as defined in the HCM are provided in Appendix A for signalized and
unsignalized intersections. Typically LOS D is considered acceptable, with LOS A representing minimal
delay, and LOS F indicating failing conditions. The results of the analysis of existing conditions are presented
in Appendix B and are summarized in Table 1.
The results of the existing conditions analysis indicates that overall all study intersections currently operate
acceptably at a LOS D or better; however, several approaches and movements currently operate at a LOS E
or F. At the intersection of 12 Mile Road & Campbell Road, the eastbound approach currently operates at a
LOS E. At the intersection of 12 Mile Road & Stephenson Highway, the southbound approach and left turn
movement currently operate at a LOS E.
Observation of the network simulation indicates that the southbound left turn queue from Stephenson
Highway to 12 Mile Road periodically occupies available storage length during the PM peak hour; however,
the queue dissipates and is not present throughout the duration of the peak period. At all other study
intersections, vehicle queues are observed to be processed acceptably.
In order to improve traffic operations to a LOS D or better for all intersection approaches and movements in
the existing condition, signal cycle length and timing changes were investigated. The results of this analysis
indicate that a signal cycle length of 90 seconds at the intersection of 12 Mile Road & Campbell Road would
provide an acceptable LOS D or better for all approaches and movements. At the intersection of 12 Mile
Road & Stephenson Highway, minor signal timing modifications would improve the southbound approach to a
LOS D, while maintaining acceptable levels on the other approaches as shown in Table 2.
In order to determine the applicable traffic growth rate for the existing traffic volumes to project build-out,
SEMCOG historical traffic data was referenced. The SEMCOG data indicate that traffic volumes in the study
area have remained relatively constant or declined. Consistent with stagnant traffic growth patterns
throughout southeast Michigan, the background growth rate was assumed to be zero percent for this study.
Further, no background developments were identified within the vicinity of the project site. Therefore, the
background conditions without the proposed development are assumed to be equal to existing conditions.
The number of PM peak hour vehicle trips that would be generated by the proposed development was
forecast based on data published by ITE in Trip Generation, 9
Edition as well as data provided by Kroger.
The ITE land use “Supermarket” best describes the proposed Kroger Marketplace store. However, the
majority of data available for this land use is for supermarkets with less than 100,000 SF of Gross Floor Area
(GFA). Therefore, the ITE data were compared to customer count data provided by Kroger for three Kroger
Marketplace stores to determine an appropriate rate.
Daily customer counts were provided for Tuesday, Wednesday, and Thursday three different stores for two
separate weeks. The average number of daily customers was calculated from the data provided and was
used to forecast the average daily traffic for a Marketplace Store. This forecast indicates that the Kroger
Marketplace store generates approximately 8,800 vehicles per day. As shown in Table 3, application of the
ITE rate significantly over-estimates the number of daily trips that would be generated by the proposed
In order to determine the number of PM peak hour trips that would be generated by the proposed Kroger, ITE
data for land uses 850 (Supermarket) and 813 (Free-Standing Discount Superstore) were evaluated as they
most closely match the proposed use of the Kroger Marketplace store. This data indicates that approximately
9.3% and 8.6% of daily trips occur during the PM peak hour for a Supermarket and Free-Standing Discount
Superstore, respectively. Further, the average directional distribution during the PM peak hour for the two
uses indicates that approximately 50% of trips are inbound and 50% are outbound. Therefore, trip generation
for the proposed Kroger Marketplace during the PM peak hour was calculated to be 9.3% of the 8,800 daily
The number of PM peak hour vehicle trips that would be generated by the bank, retail, and fuel station uses
was forecast based on data published by ITE in Trip Generation, 9
Edition. The total site trip generation forecast for the proposed development is shown in Table
As is typical of retail uses, a portion of the site-generated trips are already present on the adjacent road
network and are interrupted to visit the site. These trips are known as “pass-by” trips and account for a
percentage of the total site-generated traffic. Pass-by trips result in turning movements at the site driveways,
but do not increase traffic volumes on the adjacent road network. The pass-by rate for each use was
determined based on data published in the Trip Generation Handbook, 2
Edition. For the Kroger store the
pass-by rate was calculated as the average of the pass-by rates for the Supermarket and Free-Standing
The vehicle trips that would be generated by the proposed development were assigned to the study road
network based on existing peak hour traffic patterns and the methodologies published by ITE. This
methodology indicates that pass-by trips enter and exit the development in their original direction of travel,
while new trips will return to their direction of origin. The existing traffic patterns indicate the distribution of
The site-generated vehicle trips were assigned to the study road network based on this trip distribution model
as shown on Figure 4. The site-generated trips were added to the existing traffic volumes shown on Figure 3
to calculate the future peak hour traffic volumes shown on Figure 5.
Future peak hour vehicle delays and LOS with the proposed development were calculated based on the
existing lane use and traffic control shown on Figure 2, the proposed site access plan, the future traffic
volumes shown on Figure 5, and the methodologies presented in the HCM. For this analysis, the signal
timing improvements recommended under existing conditions were assumed complete. Additionally,
SimTraffic simulations were utilized to evaluate network operations and vehicle queues. The results of the
analysis of future conditions are presented in Appendix C and are summarized in Table 6.
The future conditions results indicate that all study intersection approaches and movements would operate
acceptably at a LOS D or better except the northbound and southbound approaches at the intersection of 12
Mile Road & Stephenson Highway. These approaches would operate at a LOS E during the PM peak period.
Additionally, the westbound through movement at the intersection of 12 Mile Road & Stephenson Highway
would also operate at a LOS E.
Review of the network simulation indicates that during the PM peak hour the southbound approach at the
intersection of 12 Mile Road & Stephenson Highway experiences a long vehicle queue throughout the
majority of the PM peak period. Further, a periodic vehicle queue is observed for the westbound approach at
the intersection; however, the queue dissipates and is not present throughout the duration of the peak period.
At the intersection of 12 Mile Road & Edgeworth Avenue, a long vehicle queue is observed on the northbound
approach that periodically extends past the proposed northern and middle site driveways, blocking ingress
and egress traffic from the driveways.
Therefore, improvements to mitigate future traffic operations to be similar to existing conditions were
investigated. First, signal cycle length and timing changes were evaluated at the intersection of 12 Mile Road
& Stephenson Highway, but do not sufficiently reduce vehicle delays. Subsequently, geometric
improvements were evaluated. The results of this analysis indicate that right turn lanes should be constructed
on the northbound and southbound approaches of Stephenson Highway. With this improvement, intersection
operations would be improved to a LOS D for all approaches as shown in Table 7.
At the intersection of 12 Mile Road & Edgeworth Avenue, the northbound approach currently has one lane for
egress traffic. In order to reduce the northbound vehicle queue length from extending past the proposed site
driveways, an additional egress lane should be constructed to provide for exclusive left and right turn lanes.
Currently, a center lane for left turns exists at all proposed access points along 12 Mile Road and Stephenson
Highway to accommodate ingress left turns. In order to determine if right turn lanes should be provided at the
proposed site access points, RCOC and MDOT warrants for right turn lanes were evaluated at the 12 Mile
Road and Stephenson Highway driveways, respectively. The results of this analysis indicate that a right turn
taper only is required at all access points to 12 Mile Road and Stephenson Highway.

text.i: The conclusions of this Traffic Impact Study (TIS) are as follows:

page.text: All study intersection approaches currently operate acceptably at an overall LOS D or better.
The eastbound approach at 12 Mile Road & Campbell Road and the southbound approach at 12 Mile
Road & Stephenson Highway currently operate at a LOS E.
With the proposed existing improvements below, all approaches and movements at the study
intersections would operate acceptably at a LOS D or better.
Future site generated trips for the proposed development were forecast based on ITE data and
Under future conditions with the proposed development the northbound and southbound
approaches at 12 Mile Road & Stephenson Highway would operate at a LOS E. Further, a long
vehicle queue is observed for the northbound approach at 12 Mile Road & Edgeworth Avenue which
periodically blocks the north and middle site driveway.
With the proposed future conditions improvements below, all approaches at the study intersections
would operate acceptably at a LOS D or better.
RCOC warrants for right turn lanes indicate that right turn tapers should be constructed at the
proposed site driveways to 12 Mile Road and Stephenson Highway.

text.i: The following are recommended based on the results of this TIS:

page.text: Increase the traffic signal cycle length at 12 Mile Road & Campbell Road during the PM peak hour.
Modify the existing signal timing at 12 Mile Road & Stephenson Highway during the PM peak hour.
Construct right turn lanes on the northbound and southbound approaches at 12 Mile Road &
Construct an additional egress lane on the northbound approach at the intersection of 12 Mile Road &
Construct right turn tapers at the site driveways to 12 Mile Road and Stephenson Highway.

text.b: Level of Service Criteria for Stop Sign Controlled Intersections

page.text: The level of service criteria are given in Table 17-2. As used here, control delay is defined as the total
elapsed time from the time a vehicle stops at the end of the queue until the vehicle departs from the stop line;
this time includes the time required for the vehicle to travel from the last-in-queue position to the
first-in-queue position, including deceleration of vehicles from free-flow speed to the speed of vehicles in
The average total delay for any particular minor movement is a function of the service rate or capacity of the
approach and the degree of saturation. . . .
Exhibit 17-2. Level of Service Criteria for TWSC Intersections
Average total delay less than 10 sec/veh is defined as Level of Service (LOS) A. Follow-up times of less
than 5 sec have been measured when there is no conflicting traffic for a minor street movement, so control
delays of less than 10 sec/veh are appropriate for low flow conditions. To remain consistent with the AWSC
intersection analysis procedure described later in this chapter, a total delay of 50 sec/veh is assumed as the
break point between LOS E and F.
The proposed level of service criteria for TWSC intersections are somewhat different from the criteria used
in Chapter 16 for signalized intersections. The primary reason for this difference is that drivers expect
different levels of performance from different kinds of transportation facilities. The expectation is that a
signalized intersection is designed to carry higher traffic volumes than an unsignalized intersection.
Additionally, several driver behavior considerations combine to make delays at signalized intersections less
onerous than at unsignalized intersections. For example, drivers at signalized intersections are able to
relax during the red interval, where drivers on the minor approaches to unsignalized intersections must
remain attentive to the task of identifying acceptable gaps and vehicle conflicts. Also, there is often much
more variability in the amount of delay experienced by individual drivers at unsignalized than signalized
intersections. For these reasons, it is considered that the total delay threshold for any given level of service
is less for an unsignalized intersection than for a signalized intersection. . . .
LOS F exists when there are insufficient gaps of suitable size to allow a side street demand to cross safely
through a major street traffic stream. This level of service is generally evident from extremely long total
delays experienced by side street traffic and by queueing on the minor approaches. The method, however,
is based on a constant critical gap size - that is, the critical gap remains constant, no matter how long the
side street motorist waits. LOS F may also appear in the form of side street vehicles’ selecting
smaller-than-usual gaps. In such cases, safety may be a problem and some disruption to the major traffic
stream may result. It is important to note that LOS F may not always result in long queues but may result in
adjustments to normal gap acceptance behavior. The latter is more difficult to observe on the field than
Source: Highway Capacity Manual, 2000. Transportation Research Board, National Research Council

text.b: Level of Service for Signalized Intersections

page.text: Level of service for signalized intersections is defined in terms of delay, which is a measure of driver discomfort and
frustration, fuel consumption, and lost travel time. Specifically, level-of-service (LOS) criteria are stated in terms of
the average stopped delay per vehicle for a 15-min analysis period. The criteria are given in Exhibit 16-2. Delay may
be measured in the field or estimated using procedures presented later in this chapter. Delay is a complex measure
and is dependent on a number of variables, including the quality of progression, the cycle length, the green ratio, and
the v/c ratio for the lane group in question.
LOS A describes operations with very low delay, up to 10 sec per vehicle. This level of service occurs when
progression is extremely favorable and most vehicles arrive during the green phase. Most vehicles do not stop at all.
Short cycle lengths may also contribute to low delay.
LOS B describes operations with delay greater than 10 and up to 20 sec per vehicle. This level generally occurs with
good progression, short cycle lengths, or both. More vehicles stop than with LOS A, causing higher levels of average
Exhibit 16-2. Level-of-Service Criteria for Signalized Intersections
LOS C describes operations with delay greater than 20 and up to 35 sec per vehicle. These higher delays may result
from fair progression, longer cycle lengths, or both. Individual cycle failures may begin to appear at this level. The
number of vehicles stopping is significant at this level, though many still pass through the intersection without
LOS D describes operations with delay greater than 35 and up to 55 sec per vehicle. At level D, the influence of
congestion becomes more noticeable. Longer delays may result from some combination of unfavorable progression,
long cycle lengths, or high v/c ratios. Many vehicles stop, and the proportion of vehicles not stopping declines.
LOS E describes operations with delay greater than 55 and up to 80 sec per vehicle. This level is considered by
many agencies to be the limit of acceptable delay. These high delay values generally indicate poor progression, long
cycle lengths, and high v/c ratios. Individual cycle failures are frequent occurrences.
LOS F describes operations with delay in excess of 80 sec per vehicle. This level, considered to be unacceptable to
most drivers, often occurs with oversaturation, that is, when arrival flow rates exceed the capacity of the intersection.
It may also occur at high v/c ratios below 1.0 with many individual cycle failures. Poor progression and long cycle
lengths may also be major contributing causes to such delay levels.
Source: Highway Capacity Manual, 2000. Transportation Research Board, National Research Council
1: Campbell Road (Push Buttons) & Twelve Mile Road
4: Edgeworth Avenue/D-M-E Driveway & Twelve Mile Road
1: Campbell Road (Push Buttons) & Twelve Mile Road
